resources.string: You keep all ownership rights to your content, you can pull it down whenever you wish, and we will not sell any of your data. By agreeing to share your content with StoryMaker.cc you permit Small World News and partners to place your stories with similar stories created with Storymaker. We group them based on story types, topics, and locations.

Your story is still posted on the sharing site of your choice, but it is referenced on StoryMaker.cc as well. Title, story decription, and tags will be posted to StoryMaker.cc all other content will be references to your personal feed at your sharing site.
Learn to be a journalist while staying safe, and producing great audio, photo, and video stories.
Developed in partnership with ICFJ, you can be sure our journalism lessons will teach you to be a better reporter.
Our digital safety lessons will help you and your sources stay safe. StoryMaker aims to keep you safe no matter where your story takes you.
Stories are best suited to different mediums, whether audio, photo or video. Learn how each medium is different.
Each lesson concludes with a quiz to test your understanding.
Share your stories with the StoryMaker.cc community, and learn to be a better storymaker with each story you share.
A good story has a beginning, middle and end. Interview someone to provide more context to your story. Show us where they live. Keep it personal.
Audio, photo, and video suit different storytelling styles. Check out the lessons to learn more. Choose a medium, and learn as you go.
Use five clips to tell your story. Describe the location of your story. Introduce your primary subject. The remaining three tell a story with a beginning, middle, and end.
Assemble your clips in different orders for the most impact.
Record the sounds that tell your story, who, what. If you cannot get strong visuals, audio is a great alternative.
A picture is worth a thousand words. Show us who or what is important in your story, or how it happens.
Sometimes several photos are needed. Show us how the story happens, tell a story in a series of related images.
Capture compelling images and actions as they happen. Show us who or what is important and why.
Event stories have an established timeframe and a set place. Focus on what happens at the event. Organize your story around when the event happens, where, and why it happens at this time and place.
Issue stories examine a broad subject. Focus on how the issue affects a community or group of people. Organize your story around who it impacts and what is being done in response.
Profile a specific character. Focus on who the character is. Organize your story around the characters daily life, what happens, and how the character deals with challenges.
Breaking news is immediate. Focus on one angle. Organize your story around factoids, who, what, where, when. User narration to add context.
Stories about events with immediate importance, often scheduled, and have a clear start and end. An election or a demonstration are good news events.
Stories about events that may not have hard news implications. A sporting event, a new business in a neighborhood, emerging technology are good feature events.
Unscheduled events with important news value. A fire, a surprise announcement by a government official, or a natural disaster are good breaking news events.
Stories about issues that affect communities. A change in local government regulation or infrastructure is a good social issue.
Stories about government and the work of public officials. A story about new laws or parliament changes is a good political issue.
Stories about the broader economy or about people’s personal finance. A story about the impact of changes in government subsidies to farmers is a good economic issue.
Stories about a subject’s role in the public view. A profile of a politician running for office is a good public profile.
Stories about people and their jobs. A profile of a famous artist or athlete is a good professional profile.
Stories about a subject’s experiences, often related to events in the news. A profile with a former soldier on the anniversary of the war might be a good personal profile.
What is happening at this event?
Who is most affected by this event?
What’s the story behind this event?
What is the impact of this event?
What is happening at this event?
Why are you involved with this event?
What is the impact of this event?
When & where did this issue begin?
How is this impacting the community?
Tell us a story about how this affects your life.
What can be done to fix this issue?
How does it impact the government?
Why is this important to you personally?
What can be done to fix this issue?
What is your relationship to this issue?
How does it impact the economy?
Who will be most affected by this?
What can be done to fix this issue?
Explain a little about who you are.
Describe a moment you felt proud of your job.
How do you see your role in the future?
Who are you and what is your job?
Please explain how you do your job.
Why is this job important to you?
How do you make an impact with this job?
What is next for you with this job?
Please explain a little about who you are.
What is an important experience that happened to you?
How did this experience make you feel?
What do you do differently now?
What would you like to see happen in the future?
How does the issue impact the community?
What is being done in response?
How does the issue impact the community?
When / Where did the issue start?
What is being done in response?
How does the character deal with the challenge?
Why is the character struggling with this challenge?
How does the character deal with the challenge?
How is it being responded to?
How is it being responded to?
Server for hosting all lesson and story content
Send all network traffic through the Tor network using the Orbot app
Download lesson archives with the Android DownloadManager service
Upload story content with the Android UploadManager service
The YouTube account to use for video uploads. This MUST be registered on your device.
The SoundCloud account to use for audio uploads
The language StoryMaker will use for the user interface.

Your StoryMaker password will be emailed to you shortly. After obtaining your password, you may login at any time via the drawer menu (Accessed by swiping from the left screen edge).
